During our travels, we‚Äôll continue to convey Congress & America‚Äôs gratitude for our brave Servicemembers stationed abroad, whose service makes the region & world more stable & safe. Read my statement on our Congressional delegation to the Indo-Pacific.
https://www.speaker.gov/newsroom/73122

After a fuel stop in Hawaii, we were honored with a briefing from USINDOPACOM Leadership, as well as a visit to the Pearl Harbor Memorial and the USS Arizona.  Our Members paid our respects to the valiant Servicemembers who perished in the brutal attack on Pearl Harbor.

Under the strong leadership of President Biden, America is firmly committed to smart, strategic engagement in the region, understanding that a free and flourishing Indo-Pacific is crucial to prosperity in our nation and around the globe.

We look forward to productive meetings that will continue to inform Congress‚Äôs work to strengthen our partnerships & advance our interests.

These include peace & security, economic growth & trade, the COVID-19 pandemic, the climate crisis, human rights and democratic governance.

I'm leading a Congressional delegation to the Indo-Pacific to reaffirm America‚Äôs unshakeable commitment to our allies & friends in the region. In Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea & Japan, we‚Äôll hold high-level meetings to discuss how we can further our shared interests & values.

But our work isn‚Äôt done. We must continue to fight for critical resources to expand broadband coverage in rural America until everyone can use and access reliable and affordable high-speed internet.

Earlier this year, Congress passed the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. This legislation made a $65 billion investment in broadband including approximately $2 billion for USDA rural broadband programs.

A lack of connectivity stifles the growth and competitiveness of rural businesses, limits the productivity of farmers unable to utilize web-based and precision agriculture tools, and restricts rural residents‚Äô access to health care, education, and remote learning services.

Accessible broadband in rural areas is linked to job and population growth, increased business investment, educational opportunities, and addresses dangerous health care shortages in rural America through access to telemedicine.
Inadequate broadband connectivity in rural areas puts Americans who live in those communities at a severe disadvantage.
